newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Investors exit ADT options.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Investors exit ADT options.

text.p: The collapse of a merger pact between Republic Industries Inc and ADT Ltd sent investors scurrying out of ADT options, traders said Monday.
"Eighty percent (of the volume) is closing positions," a broker on the Chicago Board Options Exchange said, referring to ADT options.
He said most of the exiting was from arbitrageurs who were long positions in the 20 and the 17-1/2 strikes.
By 1215 CDT (1715 GMT), ADT shares in the U.S. were down 7/8 at 19 after falling to 18-5/8. About 4.15 million shares traded.
The ADT October 20 call traded about 2,575 contracts compared to open interest of 4,960. The December 17-1/2 call traded 2,130 contracts. Its open interest was 870.
On the put side, the October 20 put traded 1,225 contracts. Its open interest was 4,745.
Other actives included the November 17-1/2 calls, the November 20 calls, the November 20 puts and the December 20 and March 20 calls.
"Initially there was both buying and selling of calls and puts, but now there are a lot of calls offered," the broker said. "It looks like they're hitting volatility a little bit."
Volatility had popped to the 47 region from the low 40's off the opening but had declined back to normal levels by late morning, traders said..
Earlier on Monday, Republic and ADT said they jointly agreed to terminate their merger agreement because of recent stock uncertainty.

On July 1, the two companies announced the merger, which at the time was valued at about $5 billion. ADT shareholders were set to receive 0.92857 shares of Republic common stock for each share of ADT common. The exchange ratio was based on a price of $26 per share of ADT common.
The termination of the deal boosted Republic shares, which were ahead 1-9/16 at 28-13/16. It reached 30-1/4 intraday.
Republic options, which trade on the CBOE and the American Stock Exchange, were thinly traded.
The most active Republic option was the October 27-1/2 put, which traded a total of 995 contracts. The option's open interest was about 2,100.
In other activity, a big roll was seen in options on Liposome Co Inc on the CBOE.
The Liposome February 1997 12-1/2 call traded about 4,500 contracts and the May 1997 17-1/2 call traded 6,750.
"They just rolled a position," a trader said. "Basically the open interest moved from February to May."
Large spreads were seen in Allergan Inc options on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, where the October 35 call traded 5,000 contracts and the November 35 call traded 5,250.
"It looks like an in-the-money covered write being rolled over to pick up some premium," said Michael Schwartz at Oppenheimer, referring to the Allergan trades.
The premium on the October 35 call was 3-1/2 and the premium on the November 35 call was 4-3/8. --Gregory Crawford, 312-408-8750/E-mail: derivatives@reuters.com
